fields.question: What were the Montague-Chelmsford Reforms and what were their consequences for the people of the sub-continent?
fields.answer: The Montague-Chelmsford Reforms were a series of measures implemented by the British government in 1919 that reserved sweeping powers for itself while providing minor concessions to political parties, with the condition of accepting the right of British control. The reforms disappointed both Muslims and Hindus, leading to increased resentment among political parties due to the inclusion of the right of arrest without a warrant and detention without bail.

fields.answer: To be closer to the army's command headquarters in the north

distractors.1: To be closer to the industrially and commercially developed south
distractors.2: To be closer to the underdeveloped Punjab region in the north
distractors.3: To be closer to the commercial districts of Karachi

fields.question: What was the purpose of the One Unit Scheme introduced by Iskander Mirza in 1955?
fields.answer: To unify West Pakistan and provide equal representation in the Assembly.

distractors.1: To bring about greater efficiency and enable more rapid development
distractors.2: To unify all of West Pakistan
distractors.3: To bring about greater efficiency and enable more rapid development

fields.question: Why did General Ayub Khan feel the army should take control in Pakistan in 1956-1958?
fields.answer: To restore stability

distractors.1: To unite the political leadership of Bengal and Punjab against him
distractors.2: To unite the political leadership of Bengal and Punjab against him
distractors.3: To unite the political leadership of Bengal and Punjab against him

fields.question: What were some of the factors that contributed to the discontent in East Pakistan in the mid-20th century?
fields.answer: Economic inequality and political marginalization

distractors.1: Regular floods and a weaker industrial base
distractors.2: Regular floods and a weak climate
distractors.3: Regular floods and a weak industrial base

fields.question: Why did the people of East Pakistan feel discontented with Pakistan during the 1970s?
fields.answer: They wanted separation from Pakistan due to perceived differences and regionalism rather than national sovereignty.

distractors.1: They wanted to have their own armed forces
distractors.2: They wanted to have their own currency and fiscal policy
distractors.3: They wanted to negotiate its own trade agreements with other countries

fields.question: Why did East Pakistan want to become independent from West Pakistan?
fields.answer: It felt under-represented in the Pakistani army and civil service, and resented the political repression and lack of attention from the rest of Pakistan due to its geographical distance.

distractors.1: It wanted to have its own currency and fiscal policy with its own taxation
distractors.2: It wanted to negotiate its own trade agreements with other countries
distractors.3: It wanted to have its own armed forces

fields.question: What was the main reason for the separation of East Pakistan from West Pakistan in 1971?
fields.answer: The perceived differences between the two halves of the country and the rejection of the Awami League's demands by Ayub Khan

distractors.1: The intervention of Indian troops in East Pakistan
distractors.2: The resentment of the Awami League
distractors.3: The resentment of the people of East Pakistan

fields.question: What were the main reasons behind the growing discontent among people in East Pakistan in the early 1970s?
fields.answer: The perceived unequal distribution of wealth and power between East and West Pakistan, as well as the rejection of the Awami League's Six Point demands by Ayub Khan and the subsequent imprisonment of its leader, Mujibur Rehman.

distractors.1: The intervention of Indian troops in East Pakistan
distractors.2: The lack of industrial base in the eastern province
distractors.3: The lack of trade agreements with other countries

fields.question: What was one of the reasons why East Pakistan felt resentful towards the government of Pakistan in the mid-20th century?
fields.answer: It felt under-represented in the Pakistani army and civil service.

distractors.1: It had a weaker industrial base than the West
distractors.2: It suffered from floods
distractors.3: It received little attention from the rest of Pakistan

fields.question: Why did Ayub Khan reject the demands of the Six Points of the Awami League?
fields.answer: He believed it would lead to separation of East Pakistan from Pakistan

distractors.1: He believed it would lead to the development of Pakistan
distractors.2: He believed it would lead to the development of Pakistan
distractors.3: He believed it would lead to the development of Pakistan

fields.question: What was the main issue that led to the conflict between President Yahya Khan and the Awami League in Pakistan?
fields.answer: The Awami League's desire to limit the power of the central government over the provinces

distractors.1: The Awami Leagues desire to take over the National Assembly
distractors.2: The Awami Leagues desire to have control over their foreign exchange earned from trade
distractors.3: The Awami Leagues desire to have control over their foreign exchange earned from trade

fields.question: What were some of the successes and failures of Pakistan's relations with Bangladesh in the 1970s and 1980s?
fields.answer: Successes: Official recognition of Bangladesh, exchange of ambassadors, cooperation on trade, tourism, and media; Failures: Withdrawal from Commonwealth and SEATO, persecution and deprivation of non-Bengalis in Bangladesh, failed asset redistribution talks between Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto and Bangladeshi leaders.

distractors.1: Cooperation on trade
distractors.2: tourism and the media
distractors.3: Official recognition of Bangladesh

fields.question: What was one of the key domestic policies implemented by the leader in the context?
fields.answer: Free primary education was introduced

distractors.1: Rural Health Centres were introduced
distractors.2: All private sector schools were nationalised
distractors.3: All private sector schools were nationalised

fields.question: Why was Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto executed in 1979?
fields.answer: He was found guilty of conspiracy to murder a political opponent

distractors.1: He refused to plead for clemency to the President
distractors.2: He was found guilty of murdering a political opponent
distractors.3: He was found guilty of a crime against the country

fields.question: What was the significance of the 1973 Constitution in Pakistan's history?
fields.answer: It established a senate and safeguarded the interests of minority provinces.

distractors.1: It was the basis upon which Pakistan has been governed to the end of the 20th Century
distractors.2: It was the basis upon which Pakistan has been governed to the end of the 20th Century
distractors.3: It was the basis upon which Pakistan has been governed to the end of the 20th Century
